Brief Description: Michigan started to report probable cases and probable deaths on June 5. These were combined the probable cases into the confirmed cases, and the probable deaths into the deaths. As a consequence, a spike with 5.5k+ cases is shown in daily cases bar chart.
The spike in cases (and deaths) in Mississippi on June 22 is due to a lack of reporting by the state for the four days prior due to a reported technical issue.
NJ began reporting probable deaths today and the record for the 25th reflects these 1854 deaths not previously reported.
The count of New Yorkers who have died of COVID-19 increased by 692.
The state of Texas' Department of State Health Services changed their reporting methodology for COVID-19 deaths, resulting in a roughly 13% increase in reported fatalities from the 26th to the 27th.

Connecticut cases rise by 463 cases. 384 cases of the cases are from lab tests "performed during April-June (which) were newly reported to DPH in connection with a transition to electronic reporting by an out of state regional laboratory and for surveillance purposes have been added to the total case and test counts".
Spikes in Virginia cases are associated with the release of a backlog of testing.

A backlog of laborartory reporting has been identified in the state of Texas which is causing spikes in reporting at the county level. Data is not currently available that would allow for these positive cases to be appropriately back distributed.

Massachusetts changed their reporting methodology on August 12th.  This will introduced a drop in total cases at the county level on August 20th as the county level probable cases are shifted to a statewide aggregate. "If and when historical data becomes available we will revise the prior reporting in line with this new definition."
